parameter 1: The footage of 'Walter Ulbricht' (qv) has been cut from all re-runs due to problems with the copyright of the shown material.
parameter 2: The footage of 'Walter Ulbricht' (qv) has been cut from all re-runs due to problems with the copyright of the shown material.
parameter 3: The original version, the 2002 TV series, consisted of six episodes each just under the half-hour mark, totalling 168 minutes. The 2003 theatrical release is cut to 80 minutes, but also contains previously unseen material.
parameter 4: SPOILER - When originally aired the last scene in Robert Hartley's bedroom was followed by the music cue that would be played at the end of episodes of "The Bob Newhart Show". Recent versions of this episode, such as those airing on TVLand/Nick at Nite, replace this with the standard "Newhart" commercial music cue.
parameter 5: In the original broadcast, the famous last scene ended with a few bars of the theme from "The Bob Newhart Show". Reruns have this replaced with the standard "Newhart" theme.
parameter 6: The scene were Fay opens the medicine cabinet in the Cafe to see her earlier self in her bathroom is cut in the version shown on Chiller, though the scene still exists in the opening of subsequent episodes. Frank still mentions witnessing her changing into uniform on the Cafe's TV.
parameter 7: The original pilot, a 2-parter in JAG, was re-cut into a single-episode and shown in the middle of the first season.
parameter 8: Some of the episodes have had new narration dubbed in.
parameter 9: The series was edited down to eight 25-minute compilation episodes in 1995; these have been released on video, and are the versions used for repeats on British TV.
parameter 10: The scene were Fay opens the medicine cabinet in the Cafe to see her earlier self in her bathroom is cut in the version shown on Chiller, though the scene still exists in the opening of subsequent episodes. Frank still mentions witnessing her changing into uniform on the Cafe's TV.
parameter 11: The version edited by Orson Welles contains no narration.
parameter 12: Major changes were made to most episodes for syndication. The 60-minute episodes were edited down to 30 minute packages, with major edits to some of the 30-40 minute segments of the original shows. In cases of segments that were only 15-20 minutes in length, these were padded out by adding stock footage, newly shot scenes, and footage from Hollywood movies such as _Silent Running (1972)_ (qv) and _Fahrenheit 451 (1966)_ (qv). Most musical cues were also replaced for syndication. In order to augment "Night Gallery"'s syndicated run, episodes of _"The Sixth Sense" (1972)_ (qv) were edited down to 30 minutes, had new introductions by Rod Serling tacked on, and were added to the syndicated run of "Night Gallery."
parameter 13: When Nip/Tuck season three was released on August 29, 2006, it had two variant covers. One cover being more explicit than the other. They also have different aspect ratios. One being 1.78:1 and the other at 1.77:1.
parameter 14: Some of the episodes have had new narration dubbed in.
parameter 15: Some of the episodes have had new narration dubbed in.
parameter 16: When NBC reran this episode the following spring, the segment "Witches' Feast" was replaced with the previously unaired _"Night Gallery" (1970) {Satisfaction Guaranteed (#2.23)}_ (qv).
parameter 17: When Nip/Tuck season three was released on August 29, 2006, it had two variant covers. One cover being more explicit than the other. They also have different aspect ratios. One being 1.78:1 and the other at 1.77:1.
parameter 18: Some of the episodes have had new narration dubbed in.
parameter 19: In the director's commentary on the Vivendi Entertainment DVD, 'Nick Willing' (qv) refers to two version of the film: one for Sky Movies (which he also calls the British version) that he mentions (at 2:01:50) cut out the moment when Hook reveals to Peter that he killed Peter's father; the other for the Syfy Channel, who he mentions (at 2:45:14) wanted to end the movie on Peter and on an up-note, so their version switched the last two scenes of the screenplay and ends with Peter's return to the Lost Boys with gifts while the Sky Movies version ends with Hook looking directly at the camera after Peter returns.
parameter 20: The footage of 'Walter Ulbricht' (qv) has been cut from all re-runs due to problems with the copyright of the shown material.
parameter 21: The version edited by Orson Welles contains no narration.
parameter 22: The scene were Fay opens the medicine cabinet in the Cafe to see her earlier self in her bathroom is cut in the version shown on Chiller, though the scene still exists in the opening of subsequent episodes. Frank still mentions witnessing her changing into uniform on the Cafe's TV.
parameter 23: In episode #6, "No Tigers at the Circus," Dick is seen watching a TV show, and only the theme song is heard. In the original run, it was the theme from "Mister Ed" (1961), but in reruns it was changed to the theme from "Bob Newhart Show, The" (1972).
parameter 24: Two versions of this episode exist: one has the usual first season opening titles featuring Hylda Baker and Jimmy Jewel, whilst the other uses a slower version of the theme tune and images of the Pledges as children.

parameter 47: When the "Seating & Tryouts" aired on TV, we hear a sample of No Doubt's "Keep On Dancing" when Ned, Moze and Cookie is looking a the "cool" table. But when it aired on TurboNick.com, an original musical cue was used instead.

parameter 49: When this originally aired, after Ziva handed the cell phone to Gibbs, Gibbs started counting from 9 to 7 then it cut to commercial. Subsequent airings, and even the DVD exclude Gibbs counting down.
